results.headline: ‘Coldwater,’ a Brutal Tale of Juvenile Lockup
results.summary_short: “Coldwater,” Vincent Grashaw’s first feature, is set at a juvenile reform institution in the middle of nowhere.

results.headline: Death Calls, but So Does the Environment
results.summary_short: “A Will for the Woods” is a documentary about natural burial that focuses on a psychiatrist as he prepares for his death.

results.headline: Pity the Poor Working Artist in Las Vegas
results.summary_short: The dance film “Step Up All In” tackles the travails of the working artist.

results.headline: The Beauty of the Moment Blurs the Pain of Memory
results.summary_short: Joaquim Pinto and his husband open their lives to the audience in “What Now? Remind Me.”

results.headline: Life and Loves of a Brooklyn Bank Robber
results.summary_short: The documentary “The Dog” examines John Wojtowicz, the real-life model for Al Pacino’s character in Sidney Lumet’s 1975 classic, “Dog Day Afternoon.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dog

results.headline: An Expert in Disaster
results.summary_short: The director Steven Quale brings his expertise in orchestrating destruction to “Into the Storm.”

results.headline: The Invisible but All-Seeing Servant
results.summary_short: In “The Maid’s Room,” a live-in maid in the Hamptons gains some leverage over her employers.

results.headline: From Gate-Crashing to the Grammys
results.summary_short: A onetime film student chronicles his journey, which began by hopping a fence to get into Coachella, in “No Cameras Allowed.”

results.headline: Voyage to the Actual Bottom of the Sea
results.summary_short: In “Deepsea Challenge 3D,” James Cameron dives into a documentary project that’s autobiographical.

results.headline: Friendship Ripens Into ... Well, You Know

results.headline: Too Many Cooks Spoil the Village
results.summary_short: French haute cuisine clashes with Indian cooking in “The Hundred-Foot Journey,” starring Helen Mirren and Om Puri.

results.headline: Millennials Turned Yuppies (Really), Pulling Together
results.summary_short: “About Alex,” in which college friends reunite, features allusions to “The Big Chill,” a reunion film of another generation.

results.summary_short: “Fifi Howls From Happiness” brings Bahman Mohassess out from obscurity.

results.headline: A Family With Problems, Not All of Them Obvious
results.summary_short: The drama “After” centers on a secret that could greatly affect an upstate New York family.

results.headline: It’s an Itch That Can’t Be Clicked
results.summary_short: “Web Junkie” is a documentary that observes China’s efforts to treat young people, mostly teenage boys, who have an Internet addiction.

results.headline: A Filmmaker’s Long-Running Journey, Dense With Details and Full of Characters
results.summary_short: In “A Fuller Life,” staged readings recount the lengthy career of the director Samuel Fuller.

results.headline: Mundanity at Home, Furry Little Pet Included
results.summary_short: “The Strange Little Cat,” set primarily in a Berlin apartment, tracks a family’s day leading up to Saturday dinner.

results.headline: Holiday Visitor Who’s a Tough Sort of Gift
results.summary_short: Joe Swanberg’s modest “Happy Christmas” is a serious comedy about marriage, parenthood and creative life.

results.headline: He Feels Good, Sometimes
results.summary_short: “Get On Up,” directed by Tate Taylor (“The Help”), tells the story of the R&B and funk singer James Brown.

results.headline: The Problem With Not Growing Up
results.summary_short: In “The Almost Man,” a 30-something guy finds that there are consequences to his lingering adolescence.
